Fig 8 Enhancing thermal CO2 reduction to CO through systematically tailoring oxygen vacancies on Al-doped CeO2 and ZrO2 catalysts Li Wang Investigation Data curation a Haiyang Lin Methodology Data curation a Bonan Xiao Methodology Data curation a Jianli Yang Data curation a Xin Xiao Writing – review & editing Supervision b Zhanglong Guo Writing – original draft Supervision Funding acquisition a ⁎ a Key Laboratory of General Chemistry of the National Ethnic Affairs Commission, School of Chemistry and Environment, Southwest Minzu University, Chengdu 610041, China Key Laboratory of General Chemistry of the National Ethnic Affairs Commission, School of Chemistry and Environment Southwest Minzu University Chengdu 610041 China aKey Laboratory of General Chemistry of the National Ethnic Affairs Commission, School of Chemistry and Environment, Southwest Minzu University, Chengdu 610041, China b College of Carbon Neutrality Future Technology, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610065, China College of Carbon Neutrality Future Technology Sichuan University Chengdu 610065 China bCollege of Carbon Neutrality Future Technology, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610065, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Global warming driven by CO2 emissions poses a significant environmental challenge, prompting research into catalytic CO2 conversion technologies. Therefore, developing simplified catalyst structures with well-defined active sites is crucial for advancing this field. Herein, CeO2 and ZrO2 were chosen as catalyst due to their excellent oxygen storage capacity and redox properties in thermal CO2 reduction. Al doping was systematically varied to explore its impact on surface oxygen species and catalytic performance. Characterization techniques including H2-TPR, H2-TPD, CO2-TPD, XRD, EPR, TEM, and in-situ FTIR were employed to analyze the structure and surface properties. For Al-doped CeO2, XPS and EPR results indicated that Al incorporation increased oxygen vacancy concentration and surface reactivity, H2-TPR, H2-TPD and in-situ FTIR confirmed that Al incorporation increased H2 activation and HCOO⁻ formation, leading to the enhancement of CO2 conversion. The AlCe20 catalyst exhibited exceptional performance with a CO2 conversion of 36.66 % at 600 °C and 100 % CO selectivity. Moreover, the AlCe20 catalyst demonstrated remarkable stability over 55 h of continuous operation at 600 °C. In contrast, XRD and XPS results showed that Al doping in ZrO2 stabilized the tetragonal phase but reduced surface oxygen availability, leading to decreased CO2 conversion. The undoped ZrO2 showed the highest conversion at 15.04 % (600 °C) among the tested samples. This work provides valuable insights into the role of surface oxygen species in CO2 conversion and highlights the importance of doping strategies in catalyst design. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Strategically modulating oxygen vacancy concentration via Al doping significantly modifies CO2 conversion efficiency in CeO2 and ZrO2 catalysts. Keywords CO2 conversion CeO2 ZrO2 Al doping Oxygen vacancies Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction Global warming driven by the greenhouse effect poses a significant threat to earth, resulting in rising temperatures, extreme weather events, and disruptions to ecosystems [1,2]. Thus technologies that convert CO2 into valuable products have garnered significant attention. CO2 catalytic reduction not only helps lower atmospheric CO2 levels but also offers the potential to produce high-value-added chemicals and fuels, thereby addressing environmental challenges while supporting sustainable economic development [3–5]. Catalysts play a pivotal role in CO2 catalytic reduction, enabling efficient conversion of CO2 into useful products such as CH4 and CO under atmosphere pressure [6,7]. Among the various catalysts explored, CeO2 and ZrO2-based materials have emerged as promising candidates due to their excellent oxygen storage capacity, redox properties, and thermal stability [8–10]. These oxides serve as versatile supports and active components in numerous catalytic systems. However, practical catalysts often incorporate additional metals such as Pt, Ru, or Fe to promote specific reaction pathways, these complex structures was not arributed to understanding the relationships beteen structure and activity [11–13]. Huang et al. [14] demonstrated that Pt/CeO2 catalysts exhibit high activity for CO2 conversion, but the presence of multiple active sites made it challenging to isolate the contribution of each component. Chu et al. [15] reported enhanced performance with Ni/ZrO2 catalysts but noted difficulties in disentangling the effects of metal-support interactions. Wei et al. [16] studied the active site dependent reaction mechanism in CO2 methanation reaction on Ru/CeO2 by employing many complex and expensive characterization equipments. Such structural complexity not only hinders mechanistic studies but also complicates the optimization of catalytic performance. Therefore, developing simplified catalyst structures with well-defined active sites is crucial for advancing this field. Despite significant advancements in developing efficient catalysts for the RWGS reaction, many of which rely on transition metals as active centers, there remains a critical need for strategies that can further enhance catalytic performance, especially at elevated temperatures where practical applications often occur. Traditional catalysts, while effective in certain temperature ranges, may suffer from limitations such as complex structures, high costs, and potential deactivation. In contrast, non-noble metal oxide catalysts like CeO2 and ZrO2 offer promising alternatives due to their excellent oxygen storage capacity, redox properties, and thermal stability. However, their full potential for RWGS is yet to be realized and requires optimization of surface oxygen species. Doping with elements such as aluminum (Al) has emerged as a powerful approach to tailor the electronic structure and surface properties of these oxides. By introducing Al doping, it is possible to increase oxygen vacancy concentrations, enhance surface reactivity, and improve the reducibility of the catalysts, all of which are crucial for efficient CO2 conversion. In this attibution, the surface oxygen content of CeO2 and ZrO2 catalysts was optimized through Al doping. By systematically varying the Al content, we aim to establish a clear relationship between surface oxygen species and catalytic performance through using advanced characterization techniques such as XRD, EPR, TEM, and in-situ FTIR. Detailed insights into how Al doping affects the concentration and distribution of surface oxygen species were provided. Our results reveal that Al doping in CeO2 increases oxygen vacancy concentration, enhancing CO2 adsorption and activation, while in ZrO2, Al doping stabilizes the tetragonal phase and reduces surface oxygen availability. These findings underscore the importance of tailoring surface oxygen chemistry to achieve high catalytic activity and selectivity. The Al-doped CeO2 catalysts, particularly AlCe20, demonstrate exceptional CO2 conversion, CO selectivity and stability, highlighting their potential for industrial applications. This work not only advances the fundamental understanding of structure-performance relationships in metal oxide catalysts but also provides practical guidelines for designing efficient catalysts for CO2 conversion. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation A series of Al-doped CeO2 (ZrO2) catalysts were prepared in this work and the preparation process was as follows: calculate and weigh the specific mass of reagents, and use citric acid as a chelating agent and fuel with a chemical stoichiometric ratio of 1.5 between fuel and metal salts in this preparation process. After that, the accurately weighed citric acid was transferred to a 50 mL beaker and dissolve it with 10 mL of deionized water. Then certain amount of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O or Zr(NO3)4·5H2O and Al(NO3)3·9H2O was transferred to separate 50 mL beakers and dissolve each with 15 mL of deionized water. The above metal salt solutions were then added to the citric acid solution, and stirred for 30 min at 40 °C. After that, 0.25 g of glycine was added to the above solution and continue stirring for another 2 h to ensure homogeneity. After stirring, the solution was transferred to a 100 mL round-bottom flask, adding 50 mL of ethanol for dispersion, and evaporating the mixture by a rotary evaporator at 60 °C and 100 rpm until a viscous consistency is achieved. Then, the resulting viscous were dried and foamy sponge-like solid was obtained in an oven at 120 °C overnight. After drying, the catalyst sample was removed from the oven and loaded the powdered material into a crucible for calcination in a muffle furnace. The temperature of muffle furnace was set at 700 °C at a rate of 1 °C/min and hold at this temperature for 4 h in a static air atmosphere. Different catalysts are synthesized by adjusting the molar ratio of Al to Ce (Zr) during the preparation process. The molar ratios of Ce (Zr) to Al are controlled at 10:1, 20:1, 50:1, and 200:1, and the corresponding catalysts are named as AlCe(Zr)10, AlCe(Zr)20, AlCe(Zr)50, and AlCe(Zr)200, respectively. Besides, the catalysts without Al doping are named as CeO2 and ZrO2. 2.2 Characterizations X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 1.5406 Å). The samples were scanned at a rate of 10°/min over a 2θ range of 20°–80° to identify the crystal structure and phase composition. The specific surface area and pore structure of the samples were characterized using nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms at 77 K. Measurements were performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface area and porosity analyzer. Prior to the analysis, the samples were subjected to degassing in a vacuum at 200 °C for 24 h.The specific surface area was calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, and pore size distributions were derived from the desorption branches of the isotherms using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker A300 EPR spectrometer operating at X-band frequencies. The samples were analyzed at room temperature, and the spectra were recorded with a microwave frequency of 9.8 GHz, a modulation frequency of 100 kHz, and a modulation amplitude of 1 G. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) observations were carried out on a Thermo Scientific Talos F200X operating at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. The samples were prepared by dispersing the powdered material in ethanol and dropping the suspension onto carbon-coated copper grids. High-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images were acquired to investigate the crystalline structure and morphological features. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha system equipped with an Al Kα X-ray source (1486.6 eV). The binding energies were calibrated using the C 1 s peak at 284.6 eV as a reference. High-resolution spectra were acquired for Ce 3d, O 1 s, Zr 3d, and Al 2p regions to determine the chemical states and surface composition of the samples. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were performed on a TP-5076 chemisorption analyzer. Typically, 50 mg of the sample was loaded into a quartz reactor and pretreated in nitrogen at 200 °C for 1 h. The reduction was carried out by switching to a 5 % H2/N2 gas mixture while heating from room temperature to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. The H2 consumption was monitored using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). H2 temperature-programmed desorption (H2-TPD) experiments were conducted on a BelCata II analyzer. The sample (100 mg) was first pretreated in Ar at 200 °C for 60 min to remove surface contaminants. Then 10 % H2/Ar was introduced and the sample was exposed to 10 % H2/Ar at 50 °C for 60 min. After that, the sample was switched to Ar (30 ml/min) at 50 oC, once a stable baseline was achieved at this temperature, the temperature was subsequently increased to 800 oC at a rate of 10°C/min, and the desorbed H2 was detected using a mass spectroscopy. CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) experiments were conducted on a BelCata II analyzer. The sample (100 mg) was first pretreated in helium at 200 °C for 60 min to remove surface contaminants. Then 10 % CO2/He was introduced and the sample was exposed to 10 % CO2/He at 50 °C for 60 min. After that, the sample was switched to He (30 ml/min) at 50 oC, once a stable baseline was achieved at this temperature, the temperature was subsequently increased to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min, and the desorbed CO2 was detected using a mass spectroscopy. In-situ Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer Fourier Transform Infrared spectrometer equipped with a transmission cell. The catalysts were pressed into self-supporting wafers and placed in the gas cell. Before the testing, the sample was pretreated at 200 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min for 1 h under N2 atmosphere. The reaction gas mixture (76 % H2/ 19 % CO2/5 %N2) was introduced, and spectra were collected at different temperatures and time intervals to monitor the formation of surface intermediates and reaction pathways. 2.3 Catalyst evaluation The catalytic activity of the prepared catalysts was evaluated in a fixed-bed continuous flow reactor. Typically, 0.1 g of catalyst was loaded into the reactor and pretreated in a nitrogen atmosphere at 400 °C for 1 h to remove any surface impurities. After cooling to room temperature in a nitrogen stream, the reaction gas mixture (H2/CO2/N2, 76:19:5) was introduced. The total gas flow rate was maintained at 40 ml/min, and the reaction was carried out at atmospheric pressure. The temperature was increased from 200 °C to 600 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min, and the effluent gas was analyzed using an online gas chromatograph equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) to determine the concentrations of CO2, CO, CH4, and other gaseous. The CO2 conversion and product selectivity were calculated according to the reported literature [17–19]. The long-term stability of the catalyst was assessed by monitoring the CO2 conversion and CO selectivity over a continuous operation period of 55 h at 600 °C. The reaction conditions were maintained as described above, and gas samples were collected for analysis to ensure consistent catalytic performance. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and surface of Al-doped catalysts The XRD patterns of the Al-doped CeO2 materials (CeO2, Ce10Al, Ce20Al, Ce50Al and Ce200Al) are presented in Fig. 1 a. The diffraction peaks can be indexed to the fluorite structure of CeO2 (JCPDS card no 78–0694) [20]. The major peaks observed at 2θ angles of approximately 28.55°, 33.08°, 47.48°, 56.33°, 59.09°, 69.40°, 76.70°, 79.07° and 88.41° correspond to the (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), (400), (331), (420) and (422) crystal planes of CeO2, respectively. Furthermore, the diffraction peak intensities decrease with increasing Al content, particularly noticeable for the (220) and (311) peaks. This reduction in peak intensity can be attributed to the increased disorder and defect density in the crystal lattice caused by the incorporation of Al3+ ions. The defects may act as scattering centers, leading to a decrease in the long-range order and thus a reduction in diffraction intensity. What’s more, the XRD results also show that Al doping leads to a systematic shift to higher 2θ angle in the peak positions. This shift indicates a reduction in the lattice parameter due to the substitution of larger Ce4+ ions (ionic radius: 0.87 Å) with smaller Al3+ions (ionic radius: 0.54 Å) [21,22]. The contraction of the crystal lattice is consistent with Vegard's law, which describes the linear relationship between lattice parameter and dopant concentration in solid solutions [23]. The observed shifts in peak positions and changes in peak intensities suggest that Al doping induces significant structural modifications in CeO2. The lattice contraction and increased defect density are likely to influence the electronic structure, oxygen storage capacity and catalytic activity. Fig. 1b showed the XRD patterns of the Al-doped ZrO2 materials (ZrO2, Zr10Al, Zr20Al, Zr50Al, Zr200Al). The diffraction peaks can be indexed to the monoclinic and tetragonal phases of ZrO2 [24]. The XRD results show that Al doping leads to systematic changes in the peak positions and phase composition of ZrO2. The (111) peak of pure ZrO2 is observed at 30.12°, corresponding to the monoclinic phase [25]. As the Al content increased, this peak shifts to higher 2θ angles, indicating a reduction in the lattice parameter due to the substitution of larger Zr4+ ions (ionic radius: 0.80 Å) with smaller Al3+ ions (ionic radius: 0.54 Å) [26]. XRD analysis showed systematic shifts in the diffraction peak positions for Al-doped CeO2 and ZrO2. These shifts are attributed to the substitution of larger Ce4+ or Zr4+ ions with smaller Al3+ ions, resulting in a reduction in the lattice parameter. This observation strongly suggests that Al has been incorporated into the crystal lattice of CeO2 and ZrO2. Additionally, the relative intensities of the monoclinic and tetragonal phases change with Al doping. The monoclinic phase is dominant in the undoped ZrO2, as indicated by the strong (111) peak at 30.12° However, with increasing Al content, the intensity of the tetragonal phase peaks (e.g., (200) at 35.0°) increases, suggesting a stabilization of the tetragonal phase. This phase transformation is attributed to the incorporation of Al3+ ions, which introduce compressive stress in the crystal lattice, favoring the tetragonal structure over the monoclinic structure. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of the Al-doped CeO2 and ZrO2 materials are presented in Fig. 1c. All samples exhibit type IV isotherms, characteristic of mesoporous materials, with distinct hysteresis loops in the relative pressure range of 0.4–0.9 [27]. This indicates the presence of mesopores and suggests that the materials have well-developed pore structures [28–30]. The AlCe20 and AlZr20 samples show a higher adsorption volume than that of un-doped sample CeO2 and ZrO2, this suggests that Al doping in CeO2 and ZrO2 enhances pore development. The inset in Fig. 1c shows the pore size distribution of the materials. The AlCe20 sample has a bimodal pore size distribution, with peaks around 2 nm and 10 nm, indicating the presence of both micro-mesopores and mesopores. This diverse pore structure is beneficial for enhancing mass transfer and reactant accessibility. In contrast, the AlZr20 sample shows a narrower pore size distribution, with a single peak around 3 nm, suggesting a more uniform pore structure. The CeO2 and ZrO2 samples exhibit broader pore size distributions, indicating less defined pore structures. Fig. 1d presented the EPR spectra of CeO2 and AlCe20. A distinct signal peak is observed near g = 2.003 in both samples, which is typically associated with isolated Ce3+ ions or oxygen vacancies in the CeO2 lattice [31–33]. The EPR spectrum of CeO2 shows a broad and relatively weak signal at g = 2.003, indicating a low concentration of paramagnetic centers or defects. In contrast, the AlCe20 sample exhibits a sharp and intense signal at the same g-value, suggesting an increased concentration of paramagnetic centers or defects due to Al doping [34]. This enhancement in signal intensity implies that Al incorporation into the CeO2 lattice introduces additional defect sites or modifies the local electronic environment around Ce3+ ions. Investigating morphology and crystal structure is essential for correlating sample properties with their catalytic performance. TEM analysis was conducted to examine the structural characteristics of Al-doped CeO2 and Al-doped ZrO2 materials (AlCe20 and AlZr20). The low-magnification TEM images (Fig. 2 a) show flake-like CeO2 nanoparticles with irregular shapes and sizes. The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images (Fig. 2b–d) reveal distinct lattice fringes corresponding to the (111), (200) and (220) planes of CeO2 with a lattice spacing of 0.308 nm, 0.269 nm and 0.192 nm, respectively [35,36]. This indicates a well-crystallized structure with multiple crystallographic orientations, as also evidenced by XRD analysis. The elemental mapping (Fig. 2e) reveals the presence of Al, which is uniformly distributed throughout the material. This indicates successful incorporation of Al into the CeO2 matrix. Besides, the distribution of Ce and O remains uniform among the tested material, suggesting that Al doping does not significantly change the overall structure. The structural characteristics of Al-doped ZrO2 material (AlZr20) were also conducted through TEM technology. The low-magnification TEM image (Fig. 2f) shows the overall morphology of the AlZr20 sample. The tested nanoparticles appear to be relatively small and are clustered together, forming a somewhat irregular aggregate structure, which might affect the dispersion of the catalyst and its accessible surface area for reaction. In Fig. 2g–i, the lattice spacing values of 0.294 nm, 0.186 nm, 0.314 nm,0.250 nm, 0.506 nm and 0.261 nm were measured which can be indexed to specific crystal planes of ZrO2 (101), (112), (111), (110), (100), and (002), respectively [37–39]. This result further revealed that the nanoparticles are crystalline with well-defined lattice fringes and the Al atoms are likely incorporated into the ZrO2 lattice without causing major structural distortions. The elemental mapping images in Fig. 2j provide information about the distribution of elements in the AlZr20 sample. The images for different elements (e.g., Zr in green, Al in red, and O in purple) show a relatively homogeneous distribution within the nanoparticle aggregate, this homogeneous distribution of Al suggests that Al atoms were incorporated evenly into the ZrO2 matrix. To further investigate the effect of Al contents on the morphology and crystal structure in CeO2 material, TEM technology was carried out on AlCe10 and AlCe50 samples with a higher and lower Al content than that of AlCe20, and the corresponding results were displayed in Fig. 3 . The low magnification TEM images (Fig. 3a and Fig. 3f) for different Al-doped CeO2 samples display agglomerated nanoparticles. These nanoparticles are clustered together, forming irregular aggregate structures. In the high magnification TEM images (Fig. 3b-d and Fig. 3g-i), distinct lattice fringes are observable for the nanoparticles. The measured lattice spacings, such as d = 0.313 nm, 0.271 nm, and 0.191 nm, can be indexed to specific crystal planes of CeO2 (111), (200) and (220). This indicates that Al atoms are incorporated into the CeO2 lattice in a way that maintains crystallinity and the Al-doping does not disrupt the fundamental crystalline structure of CeO2 significantly with different Al contents. Furthermore, the elemental mapping images (Fig. 3e and j) show the distribution of elements within the AlCe10 and AlCe50 samples. The maps for elements like Ce (green), Al (yellow), and O (red) reveal the elements are uniformly distributed. The TEM analysis of different Al-doped CeO2 samples indicates that the nanoparticles are crystalline with well- preserved lattice structures, and the elements are uniformly distributed with different Al-doping contents. 3.2 Redox and adsorption properties of Al-doped catalysts Fig. 4 a showed the H2-TPR profiles of the Al-doped CeO2 materials, all samples exhibited two distinct peaks within the temperature range of 300–800 °C, corresponding to the reduction of oxygen species on the CeO2 surface. The peak observed between 300 and 600 °C is associated with the reduction of the outermost surface oxygen on CeO2, while the peak was detected above 600 °C, which is linked to the reduction of lattice oxygen in the bulk phase of CeO2 [40–43]. The CeO2 exhibited a reduction peak at 509 °C, and the reduction peaks shift to higher temperatures upon Al doping. AlCe10 exhibits a peak at 554 °C, AlCe20 at 530 °C, AlCe50 at 542 °C, and AlCe200 at 554 °C. This shift indicates that Al doping increases the reduction temperature of CeO2, suggesting enhanced stability of the Ce4+ species and stronger Ce-O bonds due to the incorporation of Al3+ ions [44]. What’s more, the first reduced peak temperature was lowest on AlCe20 over the Al-doped CeO2 catalysts, this suggests the activity of the outermost surface oxygen was highest on this catalyst among the CeO2-based catalysts. Besides, the increase of low-temperature reduction peaks in Al-doped CeO2 than that of CeO2 suggests enhanced reducibility and accessibility of active sites, which is beneficial for catalytic reactions involving CO2 conversion. Furthermore, the incorporation of Al3+ ions into the CeO2 lattice leads to lattice contraction and increased defect density was also evidenced by XRD and EPR analyses. These structural changes contribute to the enhanced reducibility and stability of the material, making it more effective in catalytic applications. The H2-TPR profiles of the Al-doped ZrO2 materials are presented in Fig. 4b The profiles also show two reduction peaks on pure ZrO2 across the temperature range of 100–800 °C. The peak at 550 °C is associated with the reduction of surface oxygen species, while the peak at 790 °C corresponds to the reduction of bulk lattice oxygen [45,46]. One reduction peak is detected across all Al-doped ZrO2 samples, and the temperature of this reduction peak increased with the increase of Al content. This shift indicates that Al doping increases the structure stable of ZrO2, as evidenced by XRD analyses, resulting in the decrease of activated sites in CO2 conversion. The H2-TPD and CO2-TPD profiles of the CeO2 and AlCe20 catalysts were analyzed to evaluate their hydrogen and carbon dioxide adsorption behaviors, respectively. As shown in Fig. 4c, the H2-TPD profiles of both CeO2 and AlCe20 exhibit one obviously desorption peak, located at 112 and 122 °C, respectively. This result indicated that the interaction of H2 molecular and the surface of tested catalyst was higher on AlCe20 than that of CeO2 because more amount of oxygen vacancy existed on this catalyst. What’s more, the adsorbed amount of H2 molecular was higher on AlCe20 than that of CeO2 due to the increased concentration of oxygen vacancies and improved reducibility. This result is consistent with the H₂-TPR data, confirming that Al doping enhances the hydrogen adsorption capacity and surface reactivity of the catalyst. The CO2-TPD profiles of the CeO2 and AlCe20 catalysts are shown in Fig. 4d For the CeO2 catalyst, only a weak and broad desorption peak is observed at approximately 90 °C, indicating the presence of weakly basic sites and limited CO2 adsorption capacity [47]. This suggests that pure CeO2 possesses relatively few active sites capable of effectively adsorbing and activating CO2 molecules. In contrast, the AlCe20 catalyst exhibits a significantly stronger and sharper desorption peak at approximately 120 and 603 °C, clearly indicating a higher density of moderate-strength basic sites and enhanced CO₂ adsorption capacity. The increased intensity observed for AlCe20 suggests that Al doping effectively promotes CO2 adsorption and activation. This improvement can be attributed to the increased concentration of oxygen vacancies and modified electronic structure induced by the incorporation of Al3+ ions into the CeO2 lattice. The introduction of Al3+ ions leads to lattice distortion and increased defect density, which facilitates the formation of surface carbonate or bicarbonate species, thereby enhancing CO2 adsorption. 3.3 Chemical properties of Al-doped catalysts The elemental composition and chemical states of materials were investigated by XPS technology and the corresponding results presented in Fig. 5 . Fig. 5a showed the survey spectra of the Al-doped CeO2 materials. The spectra show distinct photoelectron peaks corresponding to Ce 3d, O 1 s, and Al 2p, indicating the presence of these elements on the surface of the materials. The absence of other significant peaks suggests high purity of the samples. The Al 2p spectra of the Al-doped CeO2 are presented in Fig. 5b The Al 2p peaks are observed in the binding energy range of 70–76 eV. The Al 2p peaks are centered around 73.56 eV, which is consistent with Al3+ in an oxidized state, typically associated with Al2O3 [48]. This confirms that Al is successfully incorporated into the CeO2 matrix and exists in a stable oxidized form on the surface. The slight shifts in binding energy across different doping levels suggest minor variations in the local electronic environment or interactions between Al and the CeO2 lattice. Besides, the intensity of the Al 2p peaks increases with higher Al doping levels, indicating a higher concentration of Al on the surface. This is consistent with the expected higher surface availability of Al in samples with increased doping content. Fig. 5c displayed the O 1 s spectra of the tested samples. The O 1 s peaks can be deconvoluted into three components, corresponding to different oxygen species. The main peak at 529.48 eV is attributed to lattice oxygen in CeO2, while the shoulder at 531.14 eV is associated with Ce3+-O species [49]. The broad peak at 532.31 eV corresponds to oxygen species interacting with Al or surface hydroxyl groups [50]. The primary peak at 529.48 eV remained largely unchanged across all samples. However, the Ce3+-O peak experienced a slight shift from 531.14 eV to 531.33 eV with the introduction of the Al dopant. To further analyze the variation in Ce3+-O content, the proportion of this species was determined by calculating the total peak area. The calculated results showed that the content of Ce3+−O was 13 %, 14 %, 19 %, 23 % and 18 % on CeO2, AlCe200, AlCe50, AlCe20 and AlCe10, respectively. This result indicated that the amount of oxygen vacancies in the CeO2 increased with an increase of Al content due to the lattice distortion and increased defect density, achieving to the highest on AlCe20 at 23 %, upon increasing the doped Al amount, the amount of oxygen vacancies decreased to 18 % on AlCe10 sample. Thus, a high catalytic performance was expected to obtain in the reaction of thermal CO2 reduction on AlCe20 with the highest amount of oxygen vacancies. Many studies have demonstrated that oxygen vacancies were related to the formation of Ce3+ ion in CeO2, thus the Ce 3d spectra of the Al-doped CeO2 materials were detected and the corresponding results are presented in Fig. 4d The Ce 3d spectra shows distinct peaks corresponding to Ce3+ and Ce4+ species. The Ce 3d region is complex and can be deconvoluted into several peaks, with the Ce3+ peaks typically observed at higher binding energies compared to Ce4+. The ratio of Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) was calculated at 13 %, 16 %, 20 %, 21 % and 17 % on CeO2, AlCe200, AlCe50, AlCe20 and AlCe10, respectively. The increase in Ce3+ content with moderate Al doping (AlCe20) suggests that Al incorporation promotes the formation of oxygen defects due to the introduction of oxygen vacancies. This is consistent with the results of EPR and H2-TPR that Al doping enhances the oxygen vacancy concentration on the CeO2 surface. However, higher doping levels (AlCe10) show a decrease in Ce3+ content, possibly due to saturation of oxygen vacancies or electronic structure stabilization. Based on the discussions above, it could be found that Al element was introduced in CeO2, and the content of Al doping significantly affects the amount of oxygen vacancies and Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) ratio, with moderate doping levels promoting the formation of Ce3+ species (AlCe20). These findings highlight the importance of optimizing Al doping levels to modify electronic structure. XPS analysis on Al doped ZrO2 samples were conducted out to investigate the effect of Al on ZrO2 electric structure, and the corresponding results were presented in Fig. 6 . The spectra in Fig. 6a showed distinct photoelectron peaks corresponding to Zr 3d, O 1 s, and Al 2p, indicating the presence of these elements on the surface of the materials. This result demonstrated that Al doping introduces Al3+ ions into the ZrO2 lattice, as evidenced by the presence of the Al 2p peak. To further confirm the introduction of Al in ZrO2, the Al 2p spectra of the Al-doped ZrO2 are detected and the results as presented in Fig. 6b The Al 2p peaks are observed in the binding energy range of 68–80 eV. The peak positions and shapes vary slightly with Al doping levels, indicating changes in the chemical environment of Al on the surface. What’s more, The Al 2p peaks are centered around 73.71 eV, which is consistent with Al3+ in an oxidized state, typically associated with Al2O3. This confirms that Al is successfully incorporated into the ZrO2 matrix and exists in a stable oxidized form on the surface. Furthermore, the intensity of the Al 2p peaks increases with higher Al doping levels, indicating a higher concentration of Al on the surface and the intensity achieved to the highest on AlZr10 with the highest content of Al in ZrO2. Fig. 6c showed the O 1 s spectra of Al-doped ZrO2 samples (ZrO2, AlZr200, AlZr50, AlZr20, and AlZr10). The main peak, centered around 529.80 eV, is attributed to lattice oxygen [51]. The binding energy of this peak shows a slight variation among different samples. For example, in the case of ZrO2, the peak is at 529.82 eV, while for AlZr10, it shifts to 529.94 eV. This small shift might be due to the interaction between Al and ZrO2 lattice, which can cause a change in the local electronic environment of oxygen atoms in the lattice. Peaks at higher binding energies, such as those around 530.9 - 531.1 eV, can be assigned to adsorbed oxygen species, including oxygen-containing functional groups or adsorbed oxygen molecules [52]. The relative intensity of these peaks varies among the samples. For instance, in AlZr200, the intensity ratio of this peak is relatively high compared to some other samples, indicating a relatively larger amount of adsorbed oxygen species on its surface. Lattice oxygen is crucial for maintaining the structural stability of the ZrO2 matrix, while adsorbed oxygen species can participate in various surface related reactions, such as catalytic reactions. The variation in the relative amounts and binding energies of these oxygen species with different Al doping levels suggests that Al doping can tune the surface chemistry and reactivity of ZrO2. The Zr 3d spectra of Al-doped ZrO2 samples (ZrO2, AlZr200, AlZr50, AlZr20, AlZr10) are depicted in Fig. 6d The spectra can be deconvoluted into two main peaks, corresponding to the Zr 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2 spin- orbit split components. The Zr 3d5/2 peak is centered around 184.0 eV, and the Zr 3d3/2 peak is around 181.7 eV for the ZrO2 sample. For the Al-doped samples, there are slight shifts in the binding energies of these peaks. For example, in the AlZr10 sample, the Zr 3d5/2 peak shifts to 184.19 eV and the Zr 3d3/2 peak to 181.80 eV. These small shifts in binding energies with increasing Al doping levels suggest changes in the local electronic environment of Zr atoms. The change in binding energy might be due to the difference in electronegativity between Al and Zr, which affects the charge distribution around Zr atoms. This alteration in the electronic structure might further influence the chemical reactivity and physical properties of the Al-doped ZrO2 samples. 3.4 Catalytic performance of Al-doped catalysts Fig. 7 a presents the CO2 conversion of different Al-doped CeO2 samples as a function of temperature. The CO₂ conversion of all samples increase with the rise in temperature in general because the RWGS reaction is an endothermic reaction and higher temperatures generally provide more thermal energy to overcome the activation energy barriers of CO2 molecular [63]. At lower temperatures (below approximately 300 °C), the CO2 conversion of all samples are relatively low and the differences among them are not significant. This indicates that at these temperatures, the catalytic activity of Al-doped CeO2 samples is limited, and the reaction kinetics are slow. As the temperature increases above 300 °C, the differences in CO2 conversion among the samples start to become more apparent. The AlCe20 sample shows a relatively high CO2 conversion compared to the others. For instance, at 600 °C, the conversion of AlCe20 is notably higher (36.66 %) than that of CeO2 (22.00 %), AlCe200 (24.74 %), AlCe50 (33.70 %) and AlCe10 (29.51 %). This suggests that an appropriate amount of Al doping (as in AlCe20) can enhance the catalytic performance of CeO2 for CO2 conversion might be attributed to an appropriate amount of oxygen vacancies and Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) ratio on this sample, as evidenced by XPS analyses in Fig. 5. The selectivity of different Al-doped CeO2 samples (CeO2, AlCe10, AlCe20, AlCe50 and AlCe200) for CO at the reaction temperature of 600 °C was displayed in Fig. 7b All the samples exhibit a relatively high and similar level, with CO selectivity values equal to 100 %. This indicates that, regardless of the Al doping level, these Al-doped CeO2 samples have a strong preference for producing CO in the reaction system. The consistency in CO selectivity across different samples suggests that the fundamental catalytic pathway towards CO formation is not significantly affected by the amount of Al doping within the tested range. Regarding CH4 selectivity, the values for all samples are relatively low at 0 %. This further confirms that the reaction over these Al-doped CeO2 catalysts favors the production of CO rather than CH4. Fig. 7c illustrates the relationship between the CO2 conversion of Al-doped CeO2 samples at different temperatures (400 °C, 500 °C, 600 °C) and the Ce3+ content. The CO2 conversion increased as the temperature rise from 400 to 600 °C on all samples, and the highest CO2 conversion was obtained on AlCe20 at 600 °C, as discussed in the previous analysis. The dotted line representing the Ce3+ content shows an upward trend first and then a downward trend. The samples with higher Ce3+ content generally correspond to higher CO2 conversion at the tested temperatures. This indicates a positive correlation between Ce3+ content and CO2 conversion activity because the Ce3+ species could act as active sites or participate in redox cycles, which are beneficial for the activation and conversion of CO2. Fig. 7d displays the CO2 conversion of various Al-doped ZrO2 samples as a function of temperature. As the temperature increases from 200 °C to 600 °C, the CO2 conversion of all samples show an upward trend because higher temperatures provide more thermal energy, accelerating the reaction rate and thus increasing the conversion of CO2. ZrO2, the sample without Al doping, shows the highest conversion at 15.04 % (600 °C) compared to that of Al-doped ZrO2 samples throughout the temperature range. As for Al-doped ZrO2 samples, the CO2 conversion decreased with the increase of Al content in general. While Al doping stabilizes the tetragonal phase of ZrO2 (XRD, Fig. 1b), this compromises catalytic activity by reducing oxygen mobility and vacancy formation. The rigid tetragonal structure suppresses CO2 activation pathways, as evidenced by lower normalized activity (15.04 % for AlZr20 vs. 10.72 % for monoclinic ZrO2). This explains the systematic activity decline with Al doping in ZrO2, reinforcing that structural stability does not equate to catalytic superiority. This highlights the negative impact of Al doping on improving the catalytic activity of ZrO2. The selectivity diagram for Al-doped ZrO2 samples in Fig. 7e demonstrates that these catalysts possess outstanding and invariant selectivity for CO production at high reaction temperature, which was similar to that of Al-doped CeO2. This result demonstrated that RWGS process was favored on these mixed oxide catalysts. Fig. 7f presented the relationship between the CO2 conversion of different Al-doped ZrO2 samples and the surface oxygen content (Oβ) detected by XPS analysis in Fig. 6 at different reaction temperatures (400, 500 and 600 °C), it could be found that the CO2 conversion was increased with the increase of reaction temperature and ZrO2 sample showed the highest conversion as 15.04 % at the reaction temperature of 600 °C among the tested samples, as also discussed in Fig. 7d The dotted line representing the surface oxygen content shows fluctuations among the different samples, the samples with higher surface oxygen content generally correspond to higher CO2 conversion at the tested temperatures in general. Based on the results of Fig. 7c and Fig. 7f, it could be found that surface oxygen content is an important factor affecting the CO2 conversion among the Al-doped samples during the reaction because oxygen species can provide active sites for CO2 adsorption and activation. Fig. 7 g illustrates the stability of AlCe20 catalysts with the best reaction performance over a period of 55 h at the high reaction temperature of 600 °C, CO2 conversion remains relatively stable at around 43 % with only minor fluctuations throughout the long-time testing. This indicates that the active sites on the catalyst are not easily deactivated over time, and the AlCe20 catalyst has good durability in terms of its ability to convert CO2. Apart from the tested CO2 conversion, the CO selectivity is extremely high, remaining 100 % throughout the long-time testing at 600 °C. This high and stable selectivity implies that the catalyst is highly efficient in directing the reaction towards CO production and effectively suppresses side reactions that could lead to the formation of other products. Based on the result of Fig. 7g, the AlCe20 catalyst demonstrates remarkable stability both in terms of CO₂ conversion and CO selectivity. This stability is of great significance for industrial applications, as it ensures consistent product quality and efficient operation of the catalytic process without the need for frequent catalyst regeneration or replacement. To further present the advantage of the prepared sample, Fig. 7h showed the comparation result of CO yield on AlCe20 catalyst tested in this work and other catalysts reported in the literature across a range of temperatures from 350 °C to 600 °C. Our catalyst shows a distinct upward trend in CO yield with increasing temperature. It outperforms many literature- reported catalysts, especially at temperatures above 450 °C, highlighting its competitiveness and potential for applications in CO-related production processes. The results of this comparison highlight the competitiveness and potential of the AlCe20 catalyst. Its ability to achieve a high CO yield at elevated temperatures makes it a promising candidate for applications such as industrial CO production processes. 3.5 Reaction mechanism In-situ FTIR spectra was used to probe the intermediate species on the surface of the catalysts to identify the reaction pathways and the effect of Al on the catalytic performance. The FTIR spectra of CeO2 catalyst (Fig. 8a) shows the formation of formate (HCOO⁻) and carbonate (CO3 2−) species as evident from the peaks at 1618 cm−1 and 1272 cm−1, respectively. The presence of these species indicates the initial steps of CO2 activation on the CeO2 surface. Additionally, the broad peak around 3708 cm−1 could be attributed to the OH stretching vibrations, suggesting the presence of surface hydroxyl groups. The FTIR spectra of AlCe20 catalyst (Fig. 8b) exhibits similar species as CeO2 but with significant differences in intensity and additional peaks. The formate peak at 1603 cm−1 is more pronounced, and the carbonate peak at 3624 cm−1 is also visible. The OH stretching vibrations are observed at 3722 cm−1 and 3708 cm−1. The enhanced intensity of these peaks compared to CeO2 indicates a higher H2 activation and activity of AlCe20 in CO2 hydrogenation. The temperature-programmed FTIR spectra of CeO2 catalyst (Fig. 8c) shows the evolution of surface species with increasing temperature. The peaks at 1598 cm−1 (HCOO⁻), 1346 cm−1 (CH2O), and 1039 cm−1 (CO3 2−) are observed at different temperatures, which implies the formation of carbonate on the catalyst surface [64]. The peak at 2928 cm−1 and 2831 cm−1 corresponds to the CH stretching vibrations of formate and methoxide species, respectively. As the temperature increases, the peaks associated with formate and carbonate decrease, indicating their transformation into other species or desorption. The temperature-programmed FTIR spectra of AlCe20 catalyst (Fig. 8d) shows a similar trend but with distinct differences. The formate peak at 1607 cm−1 is more intense, and additional peaks at 1349 cm−1 (CO3 2−) and 1084 cm⁻¹ (CO3 2−) are observed. This indicates sustained CO2 activation and surface reaction, attributed to the enhanced surface reactivity of Al-doped CeO2. The observed IR bands suggest a Mars-van Krevelen mechanism, where CO2 is activated on the surface, forming HCOO⁻ and CO3 2− intermediates [65,66]. The peaks at 2990 cm−1 and 2842 cm−1 are associated with CH stretching vibrations of formate and methoxide species, respectively. The in-situ FTIR analysis reveals that AlCe20 catalyst exhibits higher activity compared to CeO2. The enhanced formation of formate and carbonate species on AlCe20, suggests that Al doping promotes the activation and conversion of CO2. The temperature-programmed FTIR spectra further demonstrates that AlCe20 catalyst facilitates the transformation of surface intermediates into products at lower temperatures, indicating its potential for industrial applications in CO2 hydrogenation processes. 4 Conclusions This study comprehensively investigated the impact of Al doping on the structural, electronic, and catalytic properties of CeO2 and ZrO2 materials. For Al-doped CeO2, the results showed that Al doping led to lattice contraction, increased defect density, and a higher concentration of oxygen vacancies. These structural and electronic modifications enhanced the reducibility and surface reactivity of CeO2, resulting in improved CO2 conversion. The AlCe20 sample exhibited the highest CO2 conversion and excellent stability during long-term testing, attributed to its optimal oxygen vacancy concentration and Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) ratio. In contrast, for Al-doped ZrO2, the incorporation of Al stabilized the tetragonal phase and increased the reduction temperature, indicating enhanced structural stability. However, this increased stability was accompanied by a decrease in surface oxygen content and active sites available for CO2 conversion. Consequently, the CO2 conversion of Al-doped ZrO2 samples generally decreased with increasing Al content, with the undoped ZrO2 showing the highest conversion. Overall, Al doping was found to be beneficial for enhancing the catalytic performance of CeO2 in CO₂ conversion by increasing oxygen vacancies, while it had a detrimental effect on ZrO2 due to reduced surface oxygen availability. These findings highlight the importance of surface oxygen content and doping strategies in designing efficient catalysts for CO2 conversion applications. coredata.dc:description: Global warming driven by CO2 emissions poses a significant environmental challenge, prompting research into catalytic CO2 conversion technologies. Therefore, developing simplified catalyst structures with well-defined active sites is crucial for advancing this field. Herein, CeO2 and ZrO2 were chosen as catalyst due to their excellent oxygen storage capacity and redox properties in thermal CO2 reduction. Al doping was systematically varied to explore its impact on surface oxygen species and catalytic performance. Characterization techniques including H2-TPR, H2-TPD, CO2-TPD, XRD, EPR, TEM, and in-situ FTIR were employed to analyze the structure and surface properties. For Al-doped CeO2, XPS and EPR results indicated that Al incorporation increased oxygen vacancy concentration and surface reactivity, H2-TPR, H2-TPD and in-situ FTIR confirmed that Al incorporation increased H2 activation and HCOO⁻ formation, leading to the enhancement of CO2 conversion. The AlCe20 catalyst exhibited exceptional performance with a CO2 conversion of 36.66 % at 600 °C and 100 % CO selectivity. Moreover, the AlCe20 catalyst demonstrated remarkable stability over 55 h of continuous operation at 600 °C. In contrast, XRD and XPS results showed that Al doping in ZrO2 stabilized the tetragonal phase but reduced surface oxygen availability, leading to decreased CO2 conversion. The undoped ZrO2 showed the highest conversion at 15.04 % (600 °C) among the tested samples. This work provides valuable insights into the role of surface oxygen species in CO2 conversion and highlights the importance of doping strategies in catalyst design.
